Introduction

A viral exanthem is a rash that occurs as a manifestation of a systemic viral infection.  Viral exanthems are most common in children and are often accompanied by fever or other nonspecific symptoms (eg, rhinorrhea, lymphadenopathy).  Viral exanthems are typically self-limited but can cause serious complications and public health concerns.



This article presents a general overview of viral exanthems and then briefly discusses the most common pediatric viral exanthems.  Additional details about each viral exanthem are discussed in separate dedicated articles.

Pathogenesis



The pathogenesis depends on the underlying viral infection but can involve several mechanisms, including:



  • Immune complex deposition in the skin.
  • Cytokine-mediated inflammation.
  • Cytopathic effects of skin cell infection.


Some viral exanthems (eg, measles, mumps, rubella) can be prevented with vaccines, and in these cases, the primary risk factor is immunization status.  General risk factors include exposure history (eg, school or day care attendance, travel to or residence in endemic areas), immunosuppression.

Clinical presentation and diagnosis



Most viral exanthems are diagnosed clinically based on rash morphology, distribution, pattern of spread, and prodrome, if any.  Rash morphology can vary and may include:



  • Macules:  Flat, erythematous lesions.
  • Papules:  Raised, erythematous lesions.
  • Vesicles:  Raised lesions that are filled with clear fluid.
  • Pustules:  Raised lesions that are filled with purulent fluid.


Multiple types of lesions may be present simultaneously.  In severe or atypical cases, laboratory evaluation may include serology or PCR for viral DNA or RNA.  If obtained, a complete blood count is often normal or may show nonspecific findings, such as lymphocytosis.

Management



Viral exanthems are typically self-limited, and management is generally supportive, including antipyretics, hydration, and rest.  Topical antihistamines, corticosteroids, and emollients may be considered for pruritus, if present.  Antiviral medications are generally not recommended.

Complications



Complications are rare and include primary viral infection of other organs (eg, encephalitis, pneumonia), secondary bacterial infections, and aplastic crisis in patients with underlying hematologic conditions (eg, sickle cell disease).  Some viruses (eg, rubella virus, parvovirus B19) are teratogenic if infection occurs during pregnancy, resulting in congenital infection.

Common pediatric viral exanthems

Measles (rubeola)



  • Etiology:  Measles virus, a single-stranded, negative-sense, enveloped RNA paramyxovirus.
  • Pathogenesis:  Transmission occurs through the inhalation of infected respiratory droplets, which can remain aerosolized for 2 hours.  Following transmission, the virus replicates in the respiratory tract, eventually leading to viremia and infection of other organ systems, including the skin.  The rash appears as T cells infiltrate to mount an immune response.
  • Clinical presentation (
    figure 1
    ):
    • Exanthem:  Characterized by a maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads cephalocaudally (ie, head to trunk), sparing the palms and soles (
      image 1
      ).
    • Associated symptoms:  The course of illness begins with a prodrome of fever, cough, coryza (rhinorrhea), conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots (gray-white lesions on an erythematous base) (
      image 2
      ).  The prodrome is followed by the characteristic rash.
    • General appearance:  Patients are generally ill-appearing.
  • Management:  Supportive care and vitamin A supplementation (in patients with deficiency) to reduce the risk for complications in severe cases.
  • Complications:  Primary measles pneumonia, secondary bacterial infections, and rare neurologic complications, such as acute disseminated encephalomyelitis and subacute sclerosing panencephalitis.
  • Prevention:  Live attenuated (measles, mumps, and rubella [MMR]) vaccine and airborne precautions (eg, N95 respirator mask, isolation room).

Rubella



  • Etiology:  Rubella virus, a single-stranded, positive-sense, enveloped RNA togavirus.
  • Pathogenesis:  Transmission occurs through inhalation of infected respiratory droplets.  Following transmission, the virus replicates in the respiratory tract, eventually leading to viremia and infection of other organ systems, including the skin.  The rash appears as immune complexes deposit in the skin, which causes an inflammatory response.
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Exanthem:  Characterized by a maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads cephalocaudally, sparing the palms and soles (
      image 3
      ).
    • Associated symptoms:  Fever, lymphadenopathy (eg, suboccipital, posterior auricular, and posterior cervical), and Forchheimer spots (petechiae or erythematous papules on the soft palate).  Adolescents and adults may develop arthralgia or arthritis.
    • General appearance:  Patients are generally well-appearing.
  • Management:  Supportive care.
  • Complications:  Prenatal infections can cause congenital rubella syndrome, which is characterized by sensorineural hearing loss, cataracts, patent ductus arteriosus, and petechiae or purpura (ie, blueberry muffin rash) due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.
  • Prevention:  Live attenuated (MMR) vaccine and standard infection control.

Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease)



  • Etiology:  Parvovirus B19, a single-stranded, nonenveloped DNA parvovirus.
  • Pathogenesis:  Transmission occurs through the inhalation of infected respiratory droplets or exposure to infected blood due to the virus's tropism for erythroid progenitor cells.  Following transmission, the virus replicates in the respiratory tract, eventually leading to viremia and infection of other organ systems, including the skin and bone marrow.  The rash appears as immune complexes deposited in the skin and causes an inflammatory response.  Viral replication occurs primarily in the bone marrow.
  • Clinical presentation (
    figure 2
    ):
    • Exanthem:  Characterized by an erythematous rash on the cheeks (ie, slapped-cheek rash) that spares the nasolabial folds.  A lacy, reticular rash on the trunk and extremities often follows and spares the palms and soles (
      image 4
      ).
    • Associated symptoms:  The course of illness begins with a nonspecific viral prodrome (eg, fever, diarrhea, rhinorrhea) that is followed by the characteristic rash.  Adolescents and adults can develop symmetric, polyarticular arthritis.
    • General appearance:  Patients are generally well-appearing.
  • Management:  Supportive care.
  • Complications:  Prenatal infections can cause fetal anemia (infects fetal erythroid progenitor cells), hydrops fetalis, and intrauterine fetal demise (

    ).  In patients with underlying hematologic conditions that shorten the erythrocyte lifespan (eg, sickle cell disease), infection of erythroid progenitor cells can lead to life-threatening transient aplastic crisis.
  • Prevention:  Standard infection control (eg, handwashing, avoidance of sick contacts).

Roseola infantum (exanthem subitum, sixth disease)



  • Etiology:  Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6 ), a double-stranded, enveloped DNA herpesvirus.
  • Pathogenesis:  Transmission occurs through direct contact with infected secretions (eg, saliva) or inhalation of infected respiratory droplets.  Many cases have no identifiable exposure because the virus can be shed by asymptomatic individuals.  Following transmission, the virus replicates in mature CD4+ T cells, which release proinflammatory cytokines.  The onset of the rash coincides with the production of HHV-6â€“specific antibodies, suggesting that the formation of immune complexes may be involved in the pathogenesis, although the exact pathogenesis is unknown.
  • Clinical presentation (
    figure 3
    ):
    • Exanthem:  Characterized by a maculopapular rash that starts on the trunk and then spreads to the face and extremities.  The palms and soles are not involved.
    • Associated symptoms:  The course of illness begins with 3-4 days of high fever (ie, >40 C [>104 F]).  The fever may be associated with nonspecific viral symptoms (eg, rhinorrhea, cervical lymphadenopathy).  The fever resolves abruptly and is followed by the characteristic rash.
    • General appearance:  Patients are generally well-appearing.
  • Management:  Supportive.  Antipyretics are often administered due to the increased risk of febrile seizures.
  • Complications:  Roseola infantum is classically associated with febrile seizures due to the degree of temperature elevation.


  • Prevention:  Standard infection control.

Varicella (chickenpox)



  • Etiology:  Varicella-zoster virus, a double-stranded, enveloped DNA herpesvirus.
  • Pathogenesis:  Transmission occurs through direct contact with infected secretions or inhalation of infected respiratory droplets.  Following transmission, the virus replicates in the respiratory tract, eventually leading to viremia and infection of other organ systems, including the skin.
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Exanthem:  Characterized by successive crops of pruritic macules, papules, and vesicles (
      image 5
      ) of varying stages that present simultaneously (
      figure 4
      ).
    • Associated symptoms:  The course of illness begins with a nonspecific viral prodrome (eg, fever, malaise), followed by the characteristic rash.
    • General appearance:  Patients are generally ill-appearing.
  • Management:  Supportive care.  Acyclovir may be considered for high-risk patients (eg, newborns, pregnant individuals).
  • Complications:  Primary varicella pneumonia, secondary bacterial infections, and rare neurologic complications, such as encephalitis.  Prenatal infection can result in congenital varicella syndrome, which can cause neonatal skin rash, pneumonia, hepatitis, and meningoencephalitis.
  • Prevention:  Strategies include the live attenuated vaccine and postexposure prophylaxis for susceptible individuals (eg, unvaccinated/partially vaccinated and no history of chickenpox) (
    figure 5
    ).  Airborne precautions are required when uncrusted lesions are present; contact precautions are also required.

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease



  • Etiology:  Coxsackievirus, a single-stranded, positive-sense, nonenveloped RNA picornavirus.
  • Pathogenesis:  Transmission occurs through direct contact with infected secretions or the fecal-oral route (most common).  Following transmission, the virus replicates in the gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts, eventually leading to viremia and infection of other organ systems, including the skin.
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Exanthem:  Characterized by macules, papules, and/or vesicles that involve the palms and soles but can involve other areas (eg, buttocks, arms, legs) (
      image 6
      ).  The rash is generally not painful, but there may be mild pruritus or a tingling sensation.  Some patients also develop an oral enanthem (ulcers on the tongue, cheek, and palate) that can be painful and interfere with eating and drinking (
      image 7
      ).
    • Associated symptoms:  If present, the most common associated symptoms include fever, malaise, rhinorrhea, and diarrhea.
    • General appearance:  Patients are generally well-appearing.
  • Management:  Supportive care.
  • Complications:  Patients with a severe oral enanthem are at increased risk for dehydration.  In addition, patients with eczema may develop a severe exanthem in areas typically affected by eczema (eg, eczema coxsackium).  Rare complications include myopericarditis, aseptic meningitis, and nail dystrophy.
  • Prevention:  Standard infection control, with particular attention to handwashing following diaper changes.

Summary



A viral exanthem is a skin rash that occurs as a manifestation of a systemic viral infection and is common in children.  Most viral exanthems are diagnosed clinically, based on rash morphology, distribution, pattern of spread, and prodrome (
